ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. recognizes the hazards associated with the use of highly hazardous chemicals.  As a reflection of our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws and regulations, we submit this plan to address the hazards inherent with the use of methane and ethylene.  Our program addresses safety precautions regarding the handling and operation of this covered system as well as proper training for those who operate and maintain the system.  The company training policy requires that all employees will be properly trained for a job position before assignment to that job.

Our accidental release prevention program is clearly defined by the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Program for this facility.  This prevention program follows industry-recommended standards for preventing unnecessary human exposures and reducing the threat to the health of our employees as well as to members of the community and the surrounding area.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle these chemicals, the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility and its processes, and the training that we provide our personnel.  This Plan is updated as required by law.

Our Emergency Action Plan (EAP) details the response this facility will take as a result of an uncontrolled release of ethylene or methane.  The Plan includes procedures for notification of the local emergency responders.  This Plan is current and updated as required by law and conforms to the requirements for an Emergency Action Plan as per 29 CFR 1910.38(a).

This facility has also coordinated with the local emergency responders and will maintain close contact to ensure that the responders are familiar with the system and with the general safety and accidental release program at our plant.

It is the policy of this facility to devote the time, energy, and capital toward maintaining prevention and response programs appropri

ate to the inherent dangers with the use of highly (acutely) hazardous chemicals.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. is a retail supplier of various compressed gases for industrial, commercial, and medical use.  The facility is located at 1407 Pennsylvania Avenue in South Houston, Texas.  The facility is situated approximately 0.5 miles east of Interstate 45 and 3.5 miles south of Highway 225.

Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. utilizes two regulated substances, methane and ethylene.  Each of these chemicals is purchased from an outside vendor as a gas liquefied by pressure and stored onsite in cryogenic vessels.  Facility operators then transfer each chemical from the cryogenic vessel to cylinders of varying s (up to 35 pounds).  During the filling process, a cryogenic pump is used to draw the chemical from the cryogenic vessel to the vaporizer.  At the vaporizer, the liquefied gas is heated and vaporized.  The high pressure gas is transferred to the filling stations to fill the gas cylinders.  The cylinders are stored onsite until they are purchased by a customer.  

Matheson Tri-Gas maintains up to a maximum of 24,500 pounds of ethylene and 15,570 pounds of methane on site at any one time.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. facility has implemented this Process Safety Management / Risk Management Program to manage the handling of methane and ethylene. In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed. 

In addition, Matheson Tri-Gas has developed a preventive maintenance program in which the process equipment is inspected on a regular basis. Pressure relief valves are installed on the pumps, vessels, and manifolds, while the cylinders are each equipped with a fusible relief plug. These devices protect the equipment from overpressurization.  The pumps are also equipped with pressure controls that enabl

e them to shut down during extreme pressure or temperature conditions.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

An investigation into the facility's accident history revealed that there have been no significant releases of methane or ethylene in the last five years (June 2006 to June 2011).  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from a methane or ethylene release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. facility has an emergency action plan in effect.  The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of this PSM / RMP document.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

  1.)  To save lives.
  2.)  To minimize and avoid injuries.
  3.)  To protect the environment.
  4.)  To minimize property damage.

The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, methane and ethylene health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM / RMP regulations.

Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. personnel circulate throughout the storage facility, taking note of unusual conditions.  In the event that a methane or ethylene leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger and the Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. Quality Manager.  The Quality Manager will determine what procedures and personnel are necessary to remedy the problem. Emergency agencies will also be notified as necessary as outlined in the Emergency Action Plan.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazard Analysis, performed on May 18-19, 2010, generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. fa

cility located in South Houston, Texas.  The mitigation measures include additional training, key maintenance related tests/ inspection, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures.  The Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. Quality Manager has completed several items, which were identified at the PHA, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:

1. Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
